tool.name: SlopeExclusion

param.name: demInput
param.dialogReference: The raster dataset or mosaic dataset that represents elevation values from which slope exclusion areas will be derived.
param.pythonReference: Should be in a projected coordinate system. Vertical units much match the horizontal units of the projection.

param.name: xyzUnit
param.dialogReference: Identifies the vertical units of the Input elevation raster (Foot or Meter). Vertical units for the raster much match the horizontal units of the projection.

param.name: array_config
param.expression: Single axis tracker | Fixed tilt | Custom dimensions
param.dialogReference: Applies defaults for a single axis tracker, a fixed tilt array, or allows for custom dimensions. Default dimension values for single axis tracker are: 400 ft (125 m) north-south, 7 ft (2 m) east west. For fixed tilt, default dimension values are: 14 ft (4 m) north-south, 200 ft (60 m) east-west. Choosing "Custom Dimensions" will open up inputs for custom north-south and east-west dimensions.

param.name: rowNS
param.dialogReference: The length of the tracker rows or width of fixed rack rows. Note: only will appear if custom dimensions are chosen for the Solar array configuration.
param.pythonReference: Can be an estimate of the length or width of a full row. Units must match the elevation vertical units and projection horizontal units.

param.name: rowEW
param.dialogReference: The length of the fixed rack rows or width of tracker rack rows. Note: only will appear if custom dimensions are chosen for the Solar array configuration.
param.pythonReference: Can be an estimate of the length or width of a full row. Units must match the elevation vertical units and projection horizontal units.

param.name: slopeUnits
param.dialogReference: Defines the units of the slope output: Percent or Degrees. Default: Percent.

param.name: prodLimit
param.dialogReference: The north slope production slope limit. Default: 5%. Based on site design parameters. Default value is for trackers. Fixed rack depends on GCR.

param.name: mechEWLimit
param.dialogReference: The east/west structural/mechanical/civil slope limit. Default: 15%. Based on tracker or rack technology and construction/civil limitations.

param.name: mechNSLimit
param.dialogReference: The north/south structural/mechanical/civil slope limit. Default: 15%. Based on tracker or rack technology and construction/civil limitations.

param.name: prodOutput
param.dialogReference: Output feature class dataset (polygon) that defines the exclusion areas for north slopes greater than the production slope limit.
param.pythonReference: Must not have spaces, dashes, or unique characters.

param.name: mechOutput
param.dialogReference: Output feature class dataset (polygon) that defines the exclusion areas for slopes greater than the structural/mechanical/civil slope limit
param.pythonReference: Must not have spaces, dashes, or unique characters.

tool.summary: Analyzes the directional slope of a surface and creates exclusions zones based on a solar array width and length and set slope limits by direction.
tool.usage:
This tool creates exclusion areas to help guide layout design and avoid problematic slopes.

Production slope limit is in the north-direction only and is used to help limit the production losses from tracker row planes of array that are angled to the north. Default limit is 5% slope but can be changed based on specific site design parameters.

  • Mechanical slope limit is in the each of the cardinal directions and is used to help mitigate problems and expenses involved in putting tracker arrays in the defined areas. Different tracker technologies have general slope limitations east-west between the centerline of the plane of array, and the slope of the plane of array north-south. The limit can also be driven by constructability factors. Default limit is 15% slope but can be changed based on specific tracker technology and site design parameters.

  • Outputs are two polygons, one defining the production exclusion areas and one defining the mechanical exclusion areas.

These exclusion areas are considered “soft” and do not necessarily mean that trackers should be placed in a specific area or overlap the boundaries of the exclusion polygons. However, costs will increase if trackers are placed in or over the defined boundaries.
